content.description: The natural stand start to Gill's Double Clutch if you aren't tall. Left hand starts on a crimp in the horizontal seam below the starting holds for Gill's Double Clutch. Right hand can start to the right in the same seam, or on a bad chip farther down (the lower start felt better for me, YMMV). Crimp hard and reach up to the starting holds of Gill's Double Clutch and finish that problem.
content.location: Same as Gill's Double Clutch

content.description: Climb the face of the large detached block at the end of Doug's roof.  Resist the urge to grab for the crack to your left or the aret to your right and you will be rewarded with a fun little move or two.
content.location: The right side of Doug's Roof: 1. Middle Traverse (V1), 1a. Middle Traverse Variation 1 (V1), 1b. Middle Traverse Variation 2 (V1), 2. High Traverse (V4), 3. Left Bulge (V2), 4. Direct Bulge (V6), 5. The Crack (V0), 6. Unnamed DA #3 (V0), 7. Unnamed DA #4 (V0), 8. Unnamed DA #5 (V0), 9. Unnamed DA #6 (V0), 10. Unnamed DA #7 (V0), 11. Low Traverse (V0)

content.description: Climb the zig-zagging crack to the horizontal under the roof.
content.location: The right side of Doug's Roof: 1. Middle Traverse (V1), 1a. Middle Traverse Variation 1 (V1), 1b. Middle Traverse Variation 2 (V1), 2. High Traverse (V4), 3. Left Bulge (V2), 4. Direct Bulge (V6), 5. The Crack (V0), 6. Unnamed DA #3 (V0), 7. Unnamed DA #4 (V0), 8. Unnamed DA #5 (V0), 9. Unnamed DA #6 (V0), 10. Unnamed DA #7 (V0), 11. Low Traverse (V0)

content.description: Surprisingly, between Unnamed #4 and Unnamed #6 you will find Unnamed #5.  Climb the upward and right sloping edge of the left facing triangular flake to the horizontal below the roof.
content.location: The right side of Doug's Roof: 1. Middle Traverse (V1), 1a. Middle Traverse Variation 1 (V1), 1b. Middle Traverse Variation 2 (V1), 2. High Traverse (V4), 3. Left Bulge (V2), 4. Direct Bulge (V6), 5. The Crack (V0), 6. Unnamed DA #3 (V0), 7. Unnamed DA #4 (V0), 8. Unnamed DA #5 (V0), 9. Unnamed DA #6 (V0), 10. Unnamed DA #7 (V0), 11. Low Traverse (V0)

content.description: This is the most difficult of the row of V0s at the right side of Doug's Roof.  Climb and lie-back the upward and left sloping crack on the face below the roof.  As with the others, finish in the horizontal below the roof.
content.location: The right side of Doug's Roof: 1. Middle Traverse (V1), 1a. Middle Traverse Variation 1 (V1), 1b. Middle Traverse Variation 2 (V1), 2. High Traverse (V4), 3. Left Bulge (V2), 4. Direct Bulge (V6), 5. The Crack (V0), 6. Unnamed DA #3 (V0), 7. Unnamed DA #4 (V0), 8. Unnamed DA #5 (V0), 9. Unnamed DA #6 (V0), 10. Unnamed DA #7 (V0), 11. Low Traverse (V0)

content.description: Start three feet to the right of The Crack and climb the face to the horizontal below the roof.  There's a really good move or two in there if you don't cheat by using the cracks to your left and right.
content.location: The right side of Doug's Roof: 1. Middle Traverse (V1), 1a. Middle Traverse Variation 1 (V1), 1b. Middle Traverse Variation 2 (V1), 2. High Traverse (V4), 3. Left Bulge (V2), 4. Direct Bulge (V6), 5. The Crack (V0), 6. Unnamed DA #3 (V0), 7. Unnamed DA #4 (V0), 8. Unnamed DA #5 (V0), 9. Unnamed DA #6 (V0), 10. Unnamed DA #7 (V0), 11. Low Traverse (V0)

content.description: From the carriage road climb the face and top out a few feet above.  There's a fun little move in there.  Alternately use the arete for a slightly easier variation.
content.location:
As you walk north just across from Nosedive and Retribution, on the right hand side of the Undercliff Road there is a long boulder with several vertical slices in it just before Doug's Roof. This problem climbs the first segment that you arrive at when walking from the Trapps Bridge.                

Sliced Boulder in the Doug's Roof Area: 1. Unnamed DA #1 (V0-), 2. Unnamed DA #2 (V0), 2a. Unnamed DA #2 Variation (V0)

content.description: From a platform a few steps below the Undercliff Road, climb the low angle slabby face and use the crack formed by the flake that runs to the top of the slab to top out.
content.protection: A pad, a spot and some luck.  Really, don't fall.
content.location:
As you walk north just across from Nosedive and Retribution, on the right hand side of the Undercliff Road there is a long boulder with several vertical slices in it just before Doug's Roof.  This problem starts on a dirt ledge which is a few steps below the carriage road at the start of this boulder.                

Sliced Boulder in the Doug's Roof Area: 1. Unnamed DA #1 (V0-), 2. Unnamed DA #2 (V0), 2a. Unnamed DA #2 Variation (V0)

content.description:
From a small hold in the seam between the positive sloping face and the overhanging face, move up and left to a large horizontal.  Follow this horizontal all of the way to the down climb crack left. 

  Variation 1. From the U-shaped hold left of the original start, move left to a sharp gaston before continuing up to the horizontal and finishing traverse. 

  Variation 2. Climb the original traverse, but avoid the upward and right sloping seam.
content.protection: Pads (lots of them) or one pad and someone to move it
content.location:
To the Trapps Bridge side of Doug's Roof, starting at a hold in an upward and right sloping seam on the face below the roof.                

The center of Doug's Roof: 1. Gill's Double Clutch (V4), 2. Middle Traverse (V1), 2a. Middle Traverse Variation 1 (V1), 2b. Middle Traverse Variation 2 (V1)

content.description: This is a fun way to get lots of easy mileage.   Start at the bottom right side of the South face and angle up left until you can top out on the curving crack.  The ground follows you up as you move left, so you are never too high off the deck.  And if you can make it past the crux move, the top out will be easy (5.4).  You could also go straight up the right side, but that would be better as a top rope (5.11 ish)...    The crux is moving left behind the tree to gain a tiny left angling ramp.  The tree is sort of spotting you at this point, but would probably cause an ankle injury if you had an unexpected slip.
content.protection: not a great landing, just be careful not to fall
content.location: This is on the Mental Block.  It lies across the carriage road from Bunny and Retribution.  Drop down from the carriage road on the South face to the lowest point by the SE arete.

content.description:
See beta photo. Follow the horizontal crack all the way from left to right using only the crack for hand holds.  

  For a harder V0/V0+ variation, continue right, past the end line shown in the beta photo all the way to the block at the end of the wall
content.protection: You're inches off the ground the whole time, pads will only get in the way
content.location: Runs left to right at the base of Doug's Roof

content.description: Climb up easy ground to a left-facing corner formed by the lower roof (don't continue to move up beyond this small roof), move your hands out on crimps around the corner to the right,  move your feet and pop for the heavily chalked hold about 4 feet to your right.  At this point the difficulty is over, finish by moving right and up under the higher roof.
content.protection: A pad or two and a decent spot
content.location:
Just to the left of the smaller second roof in the center of the Doug's Roof area.                

The right side of Doug's Roof: 1. Middle Traverse (V1), 1a. Middle Traverse Variation 1 (V1), 1b. Middle Traverse Variation 2 (V1), 2. High Traverse (V4), 3. Left Bulge (V2), 4. Direct Bulge (V6), 5. The Crack (V0), 6. Unnamed DA #3 (V0), 7. Unnamed DA #4 (V0), 8. Unnamed DA #5 (V0), 9. Unnamed DA #6 (V0), 10. Unnamed DA #7 (V0), 11. Low Traverse (V0)

content.description: This is listed in the guide as "Larson's Leap" but it must be "Larsen's Leap" after Steve Larsen.  Let me know if I've made a mistake and I will amend this.  Up and slightly right from the blasting hole is a good slot.  From this starting slot, get your feet up and crank for the big hold directly above.  Finish with your hands in the horizontal below the roof.
content.location:
Two good hand holds in a slot above and sligtly right from the blasting hole at the start of Doug's Roof.                

The left side of Doug's Roof: 1. The Dark Bulge (V0), 2. Blasting Hole Problem Left (V1), 3. Blasting Hole Problem Right (V2), 4. Larsen's Leap (V1), 5. Gill's Double Clutch (V4), 6. Middle Traverse (V1), 6a. Middle Traverse Variation 1 (V1), 6b. Middle Traverse Variation 2 (V1), 7. High Traverse (V4),   7a. High Traverse Variation 1 (V4), 8. Left Bulge (V2), 9. Direct Bulge (V6), 10. Low Traverse (V0)

content.description: Fun problem that starts on the slab of Doug's Roof. A couple of balancy moves on small holds gets you up to the  roof. Reach for the crack and traverse left all the way around the corner and step off. Has a variety of holds from crimps to deep pockets and good feet.
content.protection: At least one pad and a spotter. Even better if there is a spotter and one person to move the pad since this route traverses for about 10-15 feet and is fairly high.
content.location: Starts a couple of feet left of the start of "Left Bulge" in the horizontal crack that is part of the low traverse.

content.description:
The grey Williams guide to the Trapps lists the Gill Boulder problem as a no star 5.12a R rated climb.  I'm not sure what he thinks is R rated about it as the crux and thin section is less than 10 feet off the deck.  Anyway, we're writing this up as a boulder problem anyway so we can dispense with all talk of gear, although for a trad climber completing this boulder it's very tempting to go out there with a rope and a few cams to bag one's first Gunks 5.12. 

  Unfortunately, unlike the several other boulder problems that bear his name this one is no classic, although I have so far skipped turning this boulder problem into a free solo by going through the roof--maybe that bumps the quality, but I think not. 

  The problem starts from a pair of thin holds 8 feet up below a notch in the roof.  It's probably necessary to use a cheater stone or stacked pads for anyone shorter than 6' 6" to reach the first holds.  Use the left facing sloper and whatever feet you can find on the mainly blank bulging face to gain the horizontal below the roof.  If you're feeling dangerous, complete the free solo attempt by going though the notch in the roof.
content.location:
In the middle of the bulge near the left side of Doug's Roof between crack just past Larsen's Leap and the holds of the Middle Traverse variation.                

The left side of Doug's Roof: 1. The Dark Bulge (V0), 2. Blasting Hole Problem Left (V1), 3. Blasting Hole Problem Right (V2), 4. Larsen's Leap (V1), 5. Gill's Double Clutch (V4), 6. Middle Traverse (V1), 6a. Middle Traverse Variation 1 (V1), 6b. Middle Traverse Variation 2 (V1), 7. High Traverse (V4),   7a. High Traverse Variation 1 (V4), 8. Left Bulge (V2), 9. Direct Bulge (V6), 10. Low Traverse (V0)

content.description:
This is most likely the best and most aesthetic boulder problem under Doug's Roof. I imagine it's like an easier version of Andrew's Roof V9/10. Direct Bulge will probably be much harder for people less than 5'10".  

    Climb up the short slab to somewhat cryptic holds on the underside of the roof. Hike your feet up on the slab and flex your core like a champion to make a heinously long reach over the bulge to a jug. Campus the jugs to the right to down climb the easy beginning finger crack of Doug's Roof 5.11d.
content.location: Start below Doug's Roof under a 5 foot roof/bulge where 2 seams make an X on the slab under the roof. Direct Bulge is about 40 feet right of Double Clutch 5.9+ and 10 left of Doug's Roof 5.11d.

content.description: Starting with your hands on a pair of crimpers 5 and a half feet off the deck or so.  Use scant feet to get yourself off of the deck and climb the crimps up and slightly left to a jug which will allow you to gain the horizontal that runs above the problem.  As far as I can tell, this is only V0 for the tall, and becomes at least partially a campusing problem for someone less than 5' 10" or so.
content.location:
Just before the down climb crack at the extreme left side of the Doug's Roof area there is a dark bulge on the rock.                

The left side of Doug's Roof: 1. The Dark Bulge (V0), 2. Blasting Hole Problem Left (V1), 3. Blasting Hole Problem Right (V2), 4. Larsen's Leap (V1), 5. Gill's Double Clutch (V4), 6. Middle Traverse (V1), 6a. Middle Traverse Variation 1 (V1), 6b. Middle Traverse Variation 2 (V1), 7. High Traverse (V4),   7a. High Traverse Variation 1 (V4), 8. Left Bulge (V2), 9. Direct Bulge (V6), 10. Low Traverse (V0)

content.description: Climb the crack to the right of the bulge in the middle of the Doug's Roof wall to the horizontal that runs just below the roof.  The book lists this as both V1 and V0, but V0 is the correct grade.
content.location: The right side of Doug's Roof: 1. Middle Traverse (V1), 1a. Middle Traverse Variation 1 (V1), 1b. Middle Traverse Variation 2 (V1), 2. High Traverse (V4), 3. Left Bulge (V2), 4. Direct Bulge (V6), 5. The Crack (V0), 6. Unnamed DA #3 (V0), 7. Unnamed DA #4 (V0), 8. Unnamed DA #5 (V0), 9. Unnamed DA #6 (V0), 10. Unnamed DA #7 (V0), 11. Low Traverse (V0)

content.description: The book lists these problems as one and as the same grade.  They are not, so I'm breaking them into two listings.  A couple of us cruised the left side, but ultimately gave up on the right version after more attempts than it took us to complete Gill's Double Clutch (V4) to the right of us.  I went back and did the right version this morning.   From two crimps, climb up to a horizontal with a good match able hold just left of the vertical crack.  Move up and right to a thin horizontal seam below the finish of Larson's Leap, get your feet up and gun for the big horizontal.  (If there's an alternate easier version to the right, please let me know and I'll amend the entry accordingly.)
content.location:
Just above and left of the obvious blasting hole on the bulging corner at the left side of Doug's Roof.                

The left side of Doug's Roof: 1. The Dark Bulge (V0), 2. Blasting Hole Problem Left (V1), 3. Blasting Hole Problem Right (V2), 4. Larsen's Leap (V1), 5. Gill's Double Clutch (V4), 6. Middle Traverse (V1), 6a. Middle Traverse Variation 1 (V1), 6b. Middle Traverse Variation 2 (V1), 7. High Traverse (V4),   7a. High Traverse Variation 1 (V4), 8. Left Bulge (V2), 9. Direct Bulge (V6), 10. Low Traverse (V0)

content.description: The book lists these problems as one and as the same grade.  They are not, so I'm breaking them into two listings.  A couple of us cruised the left side, but ultimately gave up on the right version after more attempts than it took us to complete Gill's Double Clutch (V4) to the right of us.   From two crimps, climb up to a horizontal with a good match able hold just left of the vertical crack.  Move up and left either to an intermediate thin crimp or directly to the better hold further up and left.  Move to the horizontal above the problem.
content.location:
Just above and left of the obvious blasting hole on the bulging corner at the left side of Doug's Roof.                

The left side of Doug's Roof: 1. The Dark Bulge (V0), 2. Blasting Hole Problem Left (V1), 3. Blasting Hole Problem Right (V2), 4. Larsen's Leap (V1), 5. Gill's Double Clutch (V4), 6. Middle Traverse (V1), 6a. Middle Traverse Variation 1 (V1), 6b. Middle Traverse Variation 2 (V1), 7. High Traverse (V4),   7a. High Traverse Variation 1 (V4), 8. Left Bulge (V2), 9. Direct Bulge (V6), 10. Low Traverse (V0)

content.description: Doug's Roof is a great place to warm up.  There are a few good harder problems (The High Traverse (V4) and Gill's Double Clutch (V4)), but the two best reasons to drop by are shelter from the rain and its dozen or so easy to moderate problems.
